bestBHT.bht: Women are encouraged to be active in household duties, practicing thrift and discipline, while displaying a kind demeanor, so that no reproach may be cast on the Gospel. They should be obedient and workers at home, avoiding the temptation to become busybodies. By being discreet, chaste, and keepers at home, women can ensure that the word of God is not spoken of in an evil manner, particularly by unbelieving husbands who may judge the Gospel based on their wives' conduct.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Not churlish and niggardly, but thrifty as housewives.
That no reproach may be cast on the Gospel, through the inconsistencies of its professors.
Albert Barnes: They are not to be better known abroad than at home; they are not to omit their own duties and become 'busy-bodies' in the concerns of others.
Religion is the patron of the domestic virtues, and regards the appropriate duties in a family as those most intimately connected with its own progress in the world.
Our first duty is at home, and all other duties will be well performed just in proportion as that is.
Marvin Vincent: The mistress of the house is to add to her thrift, energy, and strict discipline, benign, gracious, heartily kind demeanor.
Obedient [υποτασσομενας] . Better, subject or in subjection.
The mistress of the house is to add to her thrift, energy, and strict discipline, benign, gracious, heartily kind demeanor.
John Calvin: When he adds, that the word of God may not be evil spoken of, it is supposed that this relates strictly to women who were married to unbelieving husbands, who might judge of the gospel from the wicked conduct of their wives."
But what if he does not speak of husbands alone? And, indeed, it is probable that he demands such strictness of life as not to bring the gospel into the contempt of the public by their vices.
As to the other parts of the verse, the reader will find them explained in the Commentary on the First Epistle to Timothy.
Archibald T. Robertson: Keepers at home are usually workers at home.
See Romans 5:7. See Colossians 3:18; Ephesians 5:22 for the same use of υποτασσομα, to be in subjection.
John Gill: To be discreet...or to be sober both in body and mind; or to be wise and prudent in the whole of their conduct, both at home and abroad.
Chaste; in body, in affection, words and actions, having their love pure and single to their own husbands, keeping their marriage bed undefiled.
Keepers at home: minding their own family affairs, not gadding abroad; and inspecting into, and busying themselves about other people's matters.
John Wesley: Discreet — Particularly in the love of their children.
Chaste — Particularly in the love of their husbands.
That the word of God be not blasphemed — Or evil spoken of; particularly by unbelieving husbands, who lay all the blame on the religion of their wives.

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse encourages women to be active in household duties, practicing thrift and discipline, while displaying a kind demeanor, so that no reproach may be cast on the Gospel. They are to be obedient and workers at home, avoiding the temptation to become busybodies in others' affairs. Religion values the domestic virtues and regards the duties of the family as intimately connected to its own progress. By being discreet, chaste, and keepers at home, women can ensure that the word of God is not spoken of in an evil or blasphemous manner, particularly by unbelieving husbands who may judge the Gospel based on their wives' conduct.

Women are encouraged to be active in household duties, practicing thrift and discipline, while displaying a kind demeanor, so that no reproach may be cast on the Gospel. They should be obedient and workers at home, avoiding the temptation to become busybodies. By being discreet, chaste, and keepers at home, women can ensure that the word of God is not spoken of in an evil manner, particularly by unbelieving husbands who may judge the Gospel based on their wives' conduct.

Women are called to be active in household duties, practicing thrift as housewives with a gracious and kind demeanor. Their obedience and commitment to working at home ensures that no reproach is cast on the Gospel. By being discreet, chaste, and keepers at home, women can uphold the integrity of the word of God, preventing it from being spoken of in an evil manner. This is particularly important in the context of unbelieving husbands, who may judge the Gospel based on the conduct of their wives.

Their obedience and commitment to working at home ensures that no reproach is cast on the Gospel. By being discreet, chaste, and keepers at home, women can uphold the integrity of the word of God, preventing it from being spoken of in an evil manner, particularly by unbelieving husbands who may judge the Gospel based on their wives' conduct.

Women are called to be active in household duties, practicing thrift and discipline, while displaying a kind demeanor, so that no reproach may be cast on the Gospel. They should be obedient and workers at home, avoiding the temptation of becoming busybodies. By being discreet, chaste, and keepers at home, women can ensure that the word of God is not spoken of in an evil manner, particularly by unbelieving husbands who may judge the Gospel based on their wives' conduct.
